It's abysmal to think that the issue on launch date has not been resolved. Although the game play optimization is more focused on graphics and realism instead of game play it runs poorly even after months of updates etc. The game when launched hits with a launch screeching noise and refuse to launch, instead freezing and a pop up screen appears saying it couldn't run. Skipping the launch video would probably fix it like cs did but no options are available for that. Many fixes and weeks goes by nothing works. Every tutorial that promises to fix it wouldn't work, reinstalling it doesn't work. The game was able to run with little issues except for crashes here there and then but this is unacceptable and for me a huge disappointment to even consider giving this game a second chance buying skins and let alone buy the game back again.

Good old CoD!


[h1] Missed opportunities. Disappointment for long-time fans. [/h1]


[b]Campaign, multiplayer and coop special operations feel like an excuse, a mediocre prelude to the certainly successful upcoming Warzone II Battle Royale. Disappointing for fans of a good CoD solo campaign, fast gun n run close quarter action in classical multiplayer and those that search excellence in zombie coop. [/b]

Before jumping into details, I would like to underline that the review is based on my experience of 10 hours multiplayer beta and early access campaign. I play CoD games since decades and defended each new title against review bombing back in the days and before they have been taking down from Steam. I am quite good in multiplayer and spend hundreds of hours overall in all different CoD titles. CoD is my favourite games series, the franchise I spend most of my gaming time in. Before MWII came out I replayed at least 4 different CoD campaigns and I am still a regular Vanguard multiplayer player and Battle-Pass buyer. The only mode I didn’t play a lot recently is Warzone. All of this to underline my authority when it comes to judge the quality of a new CoD campaign, multiplayer and coop modes. And yes, I am also grateful to Activision to be back on Steam!

Additionally, I am sure that the technical issues will mostly be solved in the coming weeks and new modes, maps etc will be added. However, we can only judge what we see for now. Keep this in mind.

[b] Campaign [/b]

The campaign is not meeting my expectations and it is a low point in the overall series. First of all, the Mexican Cartel mix with Middle-Eastern terrorists’ storyline does not convince. Whereby it starts decently good, with great directed cut-scenes, with a fantastically good-looking Amsterdam map, the story is falling apart the further you progress. Cabron, Hermano, well my Spanish isn’t up to date, but it feels cringe. In the end the fun you will have in a campaign of CoD does not really depend on the story, but much more on the gameplay and it is here where MWII disappoints. The magic of each CoD was always to let you get in the so called “FPS-trance state”, where shooting through the levels just feels so smooth and improving your skills through the levels. This state does not exist in MWII. Here it is all about stealth, driving missions and drone protection missions; so all missions that are far away from the action fireworks of old titles. Recently I played CoD MW1 remastered which is an excellent example of this action fireworks. The driving mission in the desert in MWII is one of the worst missions I have ever played. You see, each CoD in recent years had a major military idea behind it, from nuclear weapons, non-proliferation over terrorist groups, Middle-Eastern dictators, Emerging Disruptive Technologies (EDTs) (Advanced Warfare), private military contractors or the real spaceship battles (Infinite Warfare). Where does MWII sees itself? Realistic, more open world maybe, status quo warfare, a bit more special operations probably. Warfare on Drugs… overall disappointing.

[b] Multiplayer[/b]

In my humble opinion this is the heart of each new CoD. The fast gun n run action, close quarter maps, fast respawn and satisfying level-up mechanics. That’s the reason I play CoD over Battlefield since years. That’s the reason why I buy a new CoD each year. I really enjoyed the move from DLCs to Battle Pass seasons – this was smart. I still play Vanguard with a Battle Pass I paid 10 EUR for when I missed to profit entirely from coins in one season. So you see I am all-in and I can spend hours and hours playing the very same maps over and over again, just to see myself as the winner after each map.

What is wrong with the Multiplayer in CoD MWII? Not so much, however one issue could be the game changer in the end. The maps. The maps feel badly designed and sometimes way too big. Taken from the Invasion big maps – so called Battlefield mode. Also, sometimes you have the impression the maps are just part of the next Warzone II world map. This feels lazy. I mean even the latest maps in Vanguard were excellent in design and replayability. WWII maps were fantastic as well. How come that Activision lost the focus in MWII for regular, classical CoD maps? The answer is probably Warzone II, the mode that is not available at  the time of writing this review. Warzone II will most probably be the heart of MWII and it is now more than clear that Activision tries to capitalize the most on it. Classical multiplayer however falls victim to this and I can promise you this will cost Activision in the end a huge player base – especially on consoles –, of gamers that love to play a quick round only, that like to level up their skills by fast gameplay. 

Multiplayer might be okay and especially the Amsterdam Hotel map is fantastic. However, it is not living up to my high expectations and it adds to my overall disappointment. Probably the Battle Pass will give the multiplayer new incentives to play, new maps will come in the future and also the match making, the stability, the performance will improve until then it is fun to play but definitely not better than previous multiplayer modes. And yes, I will play it more.

[b] Coop [/b]

And now the biggest let down and which I already expected to be the weakest part of the game, since Activision was not very outspoken on this part before release.

Instead of giving us a new zombie mode or extinction mode (you remember CoD Ghosts?) we should be happy about coop special operations. You see I am one of those people wasting hundreds of hours on coop modes, horde modes and those sometimes also just solo. I love the craziness of Black Ops Zombie puzzles and easter eggs. And seeing the watch time of some zombie youtubers, I am sure I am not alone. 

CoD MWII follows here the idea of the coop special operations of MWI with the difference that this mode has at the moment huge technical issues, especially in matchmaking, that it lacks the possibility to play solo and the worst I had to map my key-binds again for every single of the three maps. 

The maps of these special operations feel like they are taken directly from the upcoming Warzone II. The enemies look much the same all over the maps. To make it short, trying all three new maps, I simply didn’t have fun.

Will it get better over time? Possible. But it won’t be a real zombie mode. I am hoping however that Activision sees this and will deliver in the next years some decent zombie mode on top of the game. As I understood Activision wants to let MWII run for two years anyways. This should be enough time for adding Extinction or Zombies.

[b] Conclusion [/b]

You see, I am a huge CoD fan and I love playing every single one of them. Each new CoD has always been one of my most anticipated video games over years. Warzone II will arrive soon and I am sure that it will live up to the expectations of Warzone I gamers worldwide. If you are not looking for Warzone but for all the modes described above, then CoD MWII is at the moment not a recommendation. I continue to play the multiplayer and will retry my luck with coop special operations, but the disappointment will stay. After reflecting thoroughly, I am unfortunately down-voting this one for now. I am more than happy to come back and upvote the game the moment I feel that it now lives up to my expectations. I thank Activision to bring the game back on Steam. Please continue to release future CoD on Steam, even if the reviews are sometimes harsh and unsubstantiated (@Microsoft).

I've got to be honest... The game sucks. I've been playing nonstop since launch to finish the mastery camo grind and it's gone downhill since. After getting to level ~150 ish and playing very well there isnt a single match where you wont go up against the sweatiest players known to man and it really kills the casual replay-ability after grinding in the beginning of the game. The seasonal prestige system SUCKS and imo is far inferior to the classic hit level 55 or whatever and then prestige and start all over again. Lastly there has literally only been like 2 handfuls of games where I dont immediately have a packet burst icon on my screen and it makes no sense lol, every other game on my pc is fine with normal latency but on cod im getting 120-150ms some games and it makes me lose my mind. In conclusion im done with this game and cant wait to buy black ops this upcoming year.

If you want to get a few good games in when you get the chance go for it, but don't be surprised when you get the lagging the broken settings, and the constant berating. If you enjoy talking crap to others I highly DO NOT RECOMMEND this game. This game has no issue with opposite teams saying some of the most disgusting trash talk but once you try to give back the same crap talk it has no issue voice banning you. Not to mention how many hackers are in the lobbies now a days. Banning when cheating doesn't really work and those players continue playing. The graphical issues get worse every update such issues being the game screen flickering, crashing unprovoked (Just sitting in a party with friends), the shaders never end up loading after these huge updates. I've put a lot of effort and money into both MW2 and MW3 and at this point after playing 1,836 hours that the space it takes up (200+GB) the issues it has and all that it is no longer worth buying or playing. 

I advise buying something else, Tbh use that 60 bucks for either a new game or Wingstop seriously.

Pros: 
-A dozen game modes that fit most playing styles 
-Lots of weapons to choose from
-Quickly join a lobby/decent-sized player base
-Can choose to stay with a lobby of players you find (doesn't always work)
Cons:
-It got even WORSE. Lose frames constantly, graphics not loading even on "extreme", stuttering and lag with -25 ping. What an absolute mess..
-The menus are absolute trash. Restarts multiple times, then reloads, then needs to restart again, find what you want, then lags and misclicks.. it's a ball ache
-There is SO much useless crap jammed into this game, it runs like an obese muppet
-With the MW3 cash grab coming out, the amount of cheaters has skyrocketed..it's insane how many there are now
-Way too many attachments with minimal/useless/illogical effects on weapons
-POS crashes more than Hellen Keller in an F1 race
-Glitchy to the point of unplayable at times
-Can be laggy even with a good internet connection
-The "updates" don't fix anything, just seem to be a way to pump more $hitty "features" in
-No way to go offline so your activity is always shown
-Cringe events, i.e. bunny heads, celeb skins, etc. makes it feel more like Fortnite than COD
-gmod functions better than this game
-I bought the Battlefield pack because of how terrible this game is.. BF is no treat sometimes, but hey, at least it functions and runs better than this dog water dumpster fire

-Update 23-FEB-24: STILL the buggiest game I've ever played.. crashes at least once a session, every time has been right in the middle of a match; extremely frustrating. Every update makes more bugs. I keep waiting for the game to improve, but it never will. If you haven't bought it yet, don't. Play a game from a company that actually cares about it's product and users.

This game is a whirlwind of emotions- I think the shear fact of growing up loving CoD and it's community is what allows me to continue playing it. Prior to purchasing this game, I have not played CoD since mw19- which was a fun experience during the "pandemic." I heard and saw good things online this Fall about this mw3 and decided I'd get back into... I truly believe it has some of the most potential as far as the movement, time to kill, and health works- but the maps suck (for the most part), the game does not get the attention from Activision it needs, it feels rushed and sloppy, the servers suck, the devs quite frankly do not care about anything except the profits. I hope the Scump & hecz Lawsuit, as well as the dimished sales, and expressed dissatisfaction with the game brings rise to a better future for CoD... or it will be a thing of the past.

TLTR: Story trash, zombies trash. SBMM and OP aim assist ruin everything with PvP. At least the PC version is nothing but a pathetic cash grab. The game is clearly designed to give casuals on console their successful moments to motivate them for microtransactions. MnK is heavily disadvantaged to a point where the dumbest bots can be good on controller because of aim assist and the strongly encouraged camping. 

The [b] story [/b] is garbage. Im pissed about how the characters are handled without ever having played the original and giving a shit about them in the first place. The areas you play in consist of stitched together Warzone assets, the writing is embarrassing.

SBMM and the combination of forced crossplay and aim assist overpowered enough to even give toddlers their moments of success ruin an otherwise promising [b] PvP [/b]. TTK a little too high and hit registration a little to inconsistent. Many maps encourage sitting on some roof with a sniper all day. The 24/7 playlists with smaller maps are fun, the rest is filled with campers and people who play the same meta for months because developers dont bother fixing the balance. MCW and the riot shield backpack are part of every lobby. 

[b] Zombies [/b] is the laziest game design there has ever been. Exact copy of the Warzone map, some contracts and zombies thrown on it and that is it. I played with the thought of doing the full camo grind for once, but one match of this was boring enough. 

[b] Warzone [/b] - also ruled by aim assist - gives people so many reasons to camp that you will always get punished for actually playing the game instead of hiding in or on one of the thousand buildings. Fighting is just a game of hide and seek and the controller clown sitting in the corner already in ADS will usually win. Playing offensively is pretty much always a disadvantage. Aim assist effectively killed this game for PC and somehow there are still some delusional clowns left saying it isnt a legal aimbot. I wonder how bad these morons would be without any technical help, but they would probably quit before anyone could see it.

This is a bit of a middle-man review, as this game is not perfect. However, the only things that I can name as "problems" in this game are easily fixable. It's just a matter of if the devs want to change it. Unfortunate as that may seem, I've not seen another game that doesn't fall victim to the same problems.
- BR problems with stacking, makes it impossible to win a fight if not hugging another player
- Store being a daily/weekly updated source of cosmetics, essentially a never-ending cesspool of worthless & mainly unattractive "DLC" that doesn't impact anything
-Lack of complete satisfaction when winning BR, completing anything mastery related in MP, or overall anything at all
- New Maps not being focused on the 3-Lane Dynamic

Now, with those problems stated, I must restate, these are problems found in every other AAA game out right now with an active fanbase. Not that every problem applies to every game, but that they may only be partially present in a game while still affecting it.

All in all though, after 330 hours, I can say it definitely is competing for playtime alongside other popular titles right now, and it isn't for nothing. The gameplay feels a LOT cleaner in this new installment, however that obviously shouldn't be everything you seek out in a game. For me, the grinds it offers have been enticing, and I appreciate the satisfaction I have after completing said task and receiving said reward.
A nice grab if on sale maybe, but I don't see a complete problem with standing price for what's received.

Just remember, same people who hate this without seeing a SINGLE thing positive are part of the PROBLEM, NOT the SOLUTION.

Absolutely broken trash game. I've purchased games for $1 that are more playable than this garbage. They're asking $100+ for this mess? How are Activision still in business? They're literally the video game developer equivalent to the Nigerian Prince Email Scam. Hackers? Check. Bugs? Check. Crashes? Check. Expensive? Check. Broken? Check. Woke? Check. 
Day One: Garry's Incident doesn't seem like such a trainwreck anymore... 

The only good thing this basket case game has going for it... are the current Cryptid skins and items. But good luck getting those when you're stuck at Level 1 for the rest of your life and none of the challenges update. They better give me all these items for free once the event ends or i'm gonna chargeback hard. I also bought the VAULT edition... and the Battle Pass is inaccessible to me. AAAAA title at work. Skull & Bones has some competition for GOTY. 

I love how it takes 1 hour to set the game up. You gotta watch the opening cutscene and credits, agree to 9 different terms and conditions, make a Call of Doody account, run pre-shaders, cycle through all the settings in the world, agree to not be mean to other players(seriously), and then you're finally able to play. 

And forget about navigating the menus... it looks like the UI was designed by a sadistic troll. You'll spend a good 10 minutes trying to figure out how to simply quit the game. Lucky for you, sometimes the game will crash and will come up with a big button that says QUIT TO DESKTOP. Putting you out of your misery... least they do one thing right.

If any company deserves to go out of business... it's Activision. Unfortunately the COD fans are akin to the in-game zombies; relentless, strong in numbers, and come back for each and every game. I am simply blown away by how terrible this game is. And it's not even Early Access. I've played Unity games, that have 1 hour of work put into them, that are more well made and less buggy than this one. ALL the positive reviews here are either trolls or bots. Which mirrors the in-game player base. 

mInOt MyEr! MiNoT hAwThOrNe! Get used to these errors... they'll plague you worse than the zombies will. Imagine being a AAAAAAAAAAA company, with years of experience, and you cannot even release a game that functions. Even IGN gave this a bad review... and there's not even that much water! If I told my wife how much I spent on this game... she'd probably divorce me and take everything... except my copy of this game. Thankfully though, according to Ubisoft, I don't own this game. 

I've been a gamer for a few years now... and I think it's finally time to retire. Please cryogenically freeze me and thaw me out when Acitivision manage to release a game on par with Black Ops 2.... or they go out of business. Whichever comes first.

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 - A Thrilling Conclusion to an Epic Trilogy

Rating: ★★★★★

Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 (MW3) is the gripping conclusion to the iconic trilogy, delivering an adrenaline-fueled gaming experience that solidifies its place in the pantheon of first-person shooters.  MW3 continues the saga of the Modern Warfare series with relentless action, intense multiplayer battles, and a gripping narrative that keeps players on the edge of their seats.

Set in a world on the brink of global conflict, MW3 plunges players into a high-stakes battle against the forces of darkness. As a member of an elite multinational task force, players must navigate through a series of heart-pounding missions across diverse locations, from the streets of New York City to the war-torn landscapes of Europe and beyond. The campaign is a rollercoaster ride of epic proportions, featuring intense firefights, jaw-dropping set pieces, and unforgettable moments that leave a lasting impact.

MW3 excels not only in its single-player campaign but also in its multiplayer component, which remains a cornerstone of the franchise. With a wealth of customizable loadouts, diverse maps, and a robust progression system, the multiplayer experience is as addictive as ever. Whether you're engaging in frenetic close-quarters combat in Team Deathmatch or coordinating tactical strikes in Search and Destroy, MW3 offers a variety of game modes to suit every playstyle.

One of the standout features of MW3's multiplayer is the introduction of Killstreaks, which reward players for stringing together consecutive kills with powerful bonuses such as airstrikes, UAVs, and attack helicopters. Mastering the Killstreak system adds an extra layer of strategy to matches, encouraging players to adopt different tactics and playstyles to achieve victory.

Visually, MW3 is a feast for the eyes, with stunning graphics that push the boundaries of what is possible on current-generation hardware. From the intricately detailed environments to the lifelike character models, every aspect of the game is meticulously crafted to immerse players in the gritty realism of modern warfare.

In addition to its stellar single-player campaign and addictive multiplayer modes, MW3 also offers a robust Spec Ops mode, which allows players to tackle a series of challenging cooperative missions either solo or with a friend. Whether you're infiltrating enemy strongholds, defusing bombs, or escorting VIPs to safety, Spec Ops offers a wealth of replay value and keeps players coming back for more.

In conclusion, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 is a tour de force of the first-person shooter genre, delivering pulse-pounding action, gripping storytelling, and addictive multiplayer gameplay in equal measure. With its epic campaign, robust multiplayer modes, and engaging cooperative missions, MW3 is a must-play title for fans of the series and newcomers alike. Strap in, lock and load, and prepare for an unforgettable gaming experience.

The release of the Modern Warfare 2 reboot was a sad day for my friend Caleb and family. Caleb's trajectory into criminality was deeply influenced by "No Russian," from the original MW2, compelling him to mirror its violence in allegiance to a local violent street gang. His subsequent crimes against his family earned him a five-year prison sentence, where he managed to rehabilitate, leaving drugs behind and embracing his love of God. However, his release coincided with the release of the rebooted Modern Warfare II, reigniting his obsession with its world, especially the character Makarov. This obsession quickly derailed his recovery, pulling him back into gang life and substance abuse when he found himself unable to join the Taliban. Sadly, this led Caleb to another violent altercation where he beat up his mother, resulting in his return to jail. Like I was saying when the original released, for some, these games create blurred lines for some people between virtual violence and its real-world implications. Decent game, but not ultimately worth it.

Ah, Call of Duty, the game that's been rehashed more times than a grandma's pot of soup. Seriously, it's like they have a 'copy-paste' button for their game development. You know you're in for a treat when you buy the latest edition and it feels like you're just playing a glorified DLC for the last one.
And let's talk about the storyline - or lack thereof. It's like they hired a bunch of monkeys to throw darts at a board filled with generic military clichés. 'Oh look, another gruff soldier saving the world from evil, how original.'
And multiplayer? Don't get me started. It's like a breeding ground for twelve-year-olds who think they're hot stuff because they can quickscope. Congratulations, Timmy, you can press two buttons in quick succession. Maybe one day you'll learn how to tie your own shoelaces.
But hey, at least they've mastered the art of microtransactions. Because nothing says 'fun' like paying real money for a digital skin that nobody will ever see because you'll be too busy getting wrecked by some dude who's been playing since he was in diapers.
So in conclusion, Call of Duty: the game that's about as fresh as month-old bread and about as satisfying as a broken controller. But hey, at least it's good for one thing - reminding us that sometimes, mediocrity sells.

This is an honest review and I will go through the aspects that I liked and disliked about the game - or thought it could be improved. I am having fun with the game and even purchased the Vault Edition.

    Gameplay is very smooth, especially the animations, great graphics and very optimized. Multiplayer feels like the good old CoD series in a way, the campaign's twist and turns are a bit confusing and the whole plot is a bit vague, but I like how flexible and open the campaign and the zombies mode are, and the greatest strength of this game is the variety of the weapons and the freedom to modify them to your liking and play-style. 

    The price could be lowered a little bit as it is pricey for many people who want to experience it, and it is sometimes a bit hard to connect to the servers. In conclusion, I am completely satisfied with the game and it has improved in different aspects whether it be subtle or obvious, compared to its predecessors.

While it is undeniably a game with outstanding graphics, realistic movements, and commendable direction, users who remember the accumulated Call of Duty experience may find themselves disappointed. The graphics and movements are almost indistinguishable from the previous installment, and compared to the remastered predecessor, the emphasis on story has significantly diminished. The vibrant direction and profound, majestic storytelling that left a lasting impression have strangely become more impoverished with each new release.

Oddly enough, despite purchasing the latest installment, it feels as if you have to run the previous game to make it function. The structure seems to resemble downloadable content (DLC) in terms of content quantity, yet it comes with a new numbering and the price tag of a new game, inevitably leading to substantial dissatisfaction. On a positive note, the game introduces a focus on multiplayer with Warzone, DMZ, zombies, and war modes, featuring new weapons and various events, demonstrating ongoing management efforts.

It is undeniably not a bad game, but when compared to the previous series, it falls short of expectations. You could have done better!

I hope this letter finds you well. I wanted to take a moment to express my admiration for "Modern Warfare 3" and why I believe it stands out as an exceptional game in the world of gaming.

First and foremost, the gameplay mechanics of MW3 are nothing short of impressive. The fluidity of movement, the responsiveness of controls, and the seamless integration of various elements make for an immersive gaming experience unlike any other. Whether you're engaging in intense firefights or navigating through intricate levels, the game mechanics are finely tuned to keep players engaged and challenged.

Moreover, the storyline and narrative depth of MW3 are truly captivating. The game takes players on a thrilling journey through a world torn apart by conflict, with high-stakes missions and unexpected plot twists keeping them on the edge of their seats. The characters are well-developed, each with their own unique motivations and backstories, adding layers of complexity to the overall narrative.

Additionally, the multiplayer aspect of MW3 is undeniably addictive. With a wide range of maps, game modes, and customization options, the multiplayer experience offers endless hours of excitement and replayability. Whether you're teaming up with friends or facing off against rivals from around the world, the adrenaline-pumping action of MW3's multiplayer never fails to disappoint.

In summary, "Modern Warfare 3" is more than just a game – it's a masterpiece of interactive entertainment. From its stellar gameplay mechanics to its gripping storyline and captivating multiplayer experience, MW3 sets the standard for excellence in gaming.

Thank you for taking the time to read this letter. I hope it serves as a testament to the remarkable qualities of MW3 and inspires you to continue enjoying all that this exceptional game has to offer.

I would not recommend MW3 as a game to buy. If you want to play the campaign or zombies they are lacking in content and don't feel fulfilling progression or story wise. 

The Multiplayer is even worse in my opinion Skill Based Match Making (SBMM) is an inconsistent system that one game will put you in the easiest game you have ever played then the next game your getting spawn camped for 20 Min by the most optimised and meta weapons that people are abusing. 

The main thing is that you cannot turn off cross play on the PC version of the game. On the console versions of the game you can turn off cross-play so you only play with people on controller. So if you play on PC without a controller you have to deal with people on open mike blowing out your ear drums and you have to deal with how strong aim assist is. 

Aim assist in this COD is the strongest i have ever seen it, people using controllers can jump around and do crazy movement and because they are strafing the aim assist is stronger and keeps their cross hair on you.
Not to mention that because you can't turn off cross play you have to deal with People Ximming ( Ximming is a cheap device that can be bought at Walmart that allows people on console use a Mouse and Keyboard as well and keep aim assist) this gives the person using it a huge advantage because not only do you get to have the precise and fast aim of M&K but they also get the major tracking that MW3 aim assist gives.

The info above from the lacking content of the campaign, the slow and repetitive zombies that can only really be done with a full squad of 4-6 people, and the Multiplayer full of hackers and cheaters makes for in my Opinion the WORST Call Of Duty of all time.

There is a very decent and fun game underneath all of the cheese somewhere. Unfortunately, Skill Based Match Making will dominate your online experience. You will have an overall average experience no matter what you do. Part of that means after having a few good games and a few average games, you will have to play in games filled to the brim with players who are far FAR better than you could every hope to be, due to having flee like reactions, godlike aim, and cheetah like movement, or worse yet are just plain cheating (Which is now proven to be actually common, this is not sour grapes. The worst thing that happens to these players is a 7 day shadow ban, which is always overturned after 7 days. In which time they use an alternative account) 

If that's not enough, you will be actively nerfed or buffed mid game based on your current performance. Your Health, your hit box and hit registration are all actively modified mid game. 

Stay clear of this until SBMM is removed (which unfortunately will never happen) unless you want a completely artificial experience. If you want to guarantee yourself a few good games, buy a weapon from the cash store and use it, you will shred all before you for a little while (Although I genuinely would recommend NOBODY buy anything from the store, if you feel like this is just a sour review hating on this franchise for no good reason then I dare you to try it and see for yourself what happens).

Genuine shame, like its predecessor there is such a good base here.

COD HQ Is the worst update of all time

Edit: Below was before this weird...CoD as a service BS that they seem to be doing now. Just be like me an accept quality for this franchise is dead and move onto another game.

Score: 8/10
Pros:  Gunplay is incredibly solid and tons of playstyles and equipment are considered and then optimized. Its one of the first CoD I can honestly say nail the gameplay in years, perhaps since the original MW2. I personally enjoy the unlock system where you have to level up all the weapons individual to get parts that then are shared with weapons of similar types. This means that by leveling up guns you don't like, you can take parts you did like from them and attach it to your favorite weapons. This encourages variation and experimentation, where you may accidentally find a new gun you like cause you wanted more parts for your old best. DMZ is absolutely a blast and is the right balance of losing and winning. Unlike Tarkov where losing is incredibly frustrating, DMZ just makes you go meh when you die, as getting back to where you were isn't long tedious grind, and the balance between having everything and not isn't too extreme. Very well done. 
Cons: For the love of god fix the constant crash to desktop. This should have been resolved before release, to the point where the game should have been delayed. This CoD is so good that having it crash is such a heart wrenching experience because you get so into the game. The amount of times my crew rage quit because we were having so much fun only to hit that CtD wall is absurd. This is probably the best CoD in a while, fix this and you can easily get folks endlessly playing.
Recommend to: People who like CoD, who want a good FPS, and want to be surprised that somehow CoD managed to become great again.
Overall: Seriously Devs, well done. This is truly the best CoD in a long time. Fix the CtD already though, or explain details so folks can at least be content that you are looking into it.

1. Practice Makes Perfect
The first and most important thing to remember is that practice makes perfect. Don't be discouraged if you don't do well at first. Keep playing and you'll get better over time.

2. Learn the Maps
Knowing the maps is essential to success in Call of Duty. Take the time to explore each map and learn the layout, including key locations and choke-points.

3. Choose the Right Loadout
Your loadout is your set of weapons, equipment, and perks. Experiment with different loadouts to find one that suits your playstyle. Try different combinations of weapons and attachments to see what works best for you.

4. Use Cover
One of the keys to survival in Call of Duty is to use cover effectively. Don't just run out into the open; instead, use walls, buildings, and other objects to take cover and avoid enemy fire.

5. Communicate with Your Teammates
Call of Duty is a team game, and communication is key to success. Use your microphone to talk to your teammates and coordinate your actions. Call out enemy positions and share information about the map.

6. Stay Calm
Finally, it's important to stay calm and focused during gameplay. Don't get frustrated if you die or make a mistake. Take a deep breath, learn from your mistakes, and keep playing.

Это именно та игра, которая превосходно демонстрирует, насколько попсовой и поверхностной может быть современная игровая индустрия.
Сначала давайте поговорим о сюжете, если его можно так назвать. История кажется скомканной и лишенной какого-либо смысла, персонажи невнятны и малоинтересны, а сюжетные повороты больше напоминают сюжет среднего боевика, чем настоящий эпический рассказ. Вам придется просто мчаться по уровням, убивая врагов, не задавая вопросов и не задумываясь над тем, почему вы это делаете.
Мультиплеер - еще одна главная проблема. Это просто бесконечное плясание на клавишах и стрельба наугад. Никакой стратегии, никакой тактики - только хаос. При этом баланс персонажей и оружия оставляет желать лучшего, и вы постоянно будете умирать от невидимых снайперов и гранат, которые кажется, прилетают со всех сторон.
Графика, конечно, приличная, но это не спасает ситуацию. В мире современных видеоигр, где есть настоящие шедевры, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 кажется устаревшей и неинтересной.
В итоге, это пример того, как игры могут быть лишены души и ограничиваться только визуальным блеском. Если вы ищете глубокий сюжет, интересный мультиплеер и умопомрачительные геймплейные моменты, вам, скорее всего, придется искать что-то другое, потому что этой игре это просто не присуще.

I've put a ton of time and money into this game but I decided to finally delete this crap and move on. Devs if you're listening: your SBMM is noticeable which means it's bad. You are constantly manipulating my experience when I play the game. There is no sense of how I stand against the "average player" because I am always being put in lobbies with people who are on par or better than myself. Then every couple of games you give me a pity round where I can do really well because you make me one of the best in the lobby. The pattern is noticeable and predictable. It's bad. It feels like shit. It's why your playerbase is dwindling. 

Fix your cheating issue. You seem extremely concerned with the competitive experience since you have level 99 SBMM enabled, but you won't take the necessary measures to meaningfully battle cheaters. Implement kernel-level anti-cheat, and take aggressive steps to combat the use of cronus-like devices. 

When you pair your implementation of SBMM with your cheating issue you have a toxic combination that sours my experience every time I log in. 

You also dropped content update support for DMZ which was the only mode that kept me around during MW2. Bring DMZ back with new maps and the new guns, remove your shit ass SBMM, and implement the necessary anti-cheat measures and I'll come back. But you won't do this, so I won't be.

Not a bad game. Sometimes very frustrating. Zombies is really fun, because the Zombies don't have auto-aim (but they do have wall hacks, just like a lot of players on here). I started getting the hang of playing again and it got fun. Then I started getting put into lobbies where at least one player in every match can make impossible shots over and over. The problem is this: They could be cheating, or they could just be using a controller. You just have to remember that you're playing call of duty. The community hasn't changed from whenever you stopped playing last. I will literally miss some shots through walls on purpose just to not get reported and shadow-banned into another sweat lobby. I don't talk so I won't get reported for unkind words or whatever it's called (and I've still been chat banned twice, lol). Still gonna play though, maybe just less. Hopefully they balance controller auto aim a bit and tweak with anti-cheat. Right now it feels like it's all working against someone who just has decent aim on a PC. Also, note: if it keeps crashing and you don't know why, update your drivers and uninstall any old key mapping software you forgot was on your HDD.

If you want something realistic, this isn't the game for you. No human - especially a soldier - is sprinting and jumping around corners into a slide, then cancel slide, into a jump and aim and shoot as soon as you land, then sprint and slide again into shooting. It's unnecessary. 

All the stupid multiplayer costumes make this game look like fortnite. I'd rather this game be kept as a serious military experience.

Getting killed by melee knife attacks is a joke. I've seen on replays people getting knifes in the hand, yet it's a one-hit kill. It's just stupid. It can take 3 shotgun blasts to kill someone, but one slash of the hand with a tiny knife and you're dead.

It is what it is. Modern COD for modern audiences. It's not realistic. Invasion is probably the best game mode.

It's clear money and greed are the only things COD is focused on at this point. It's very obvious they put way more effort and resources into bundles and malicious UI rather than focusing on improving the player experience

- Disgustingly overpriced micro-transactions (which at this point are just transactions).
- The ugliest, most brain dead UI ever seen in all of video games. 
- The after action report that you can't even get all the way through before the next match starts, and then are unable to go back and check because it doesn't save or even show you what you unlocked. So if you miss that screen, good luck finding whatever useless attachment you just got.
- The battle pass that requires a crazy amount of time to complete for casuals or any sane person.
- COD HQ being the only way to access the other CODs feels shady. They want to waste your time so you eventually cough up the money for their yearly "Most advanced COD ever!! :-D"
- SBMM making you sweat every game and focus all of your brain power just to get through a match. They claim it will encourage players to get better and play longer but I feel the opposite. I'd rather play other games after 2 or 3 matches.

It's clear that the game is designed to keep you on the application for as long as possible, and rope you into spending more money. The sluggish slides and screens and prompts are all intentional to keep your play hours up. You wanna go back and play MW2?? Yeah, have fun waiting 15 minutes for the application to restart 3 times and go through each shitty screen to get into a match. What's unfortunate is that this will never change because they know people will play and cough up their rent money/parent's money anyways. The glory days of COD are gone, unfortunately, and I don't ever see them returning. This used to be my favorite game, but this franchise has lost it's identity and it's very sad to see. Maybe Treyarch will try to save our sanity a bit and make things better, even if they just bring back some classic zombies that feel like the good old days. But I'm losing hope for that too...

Been out of FPS games for a while - Decided to give Warzone a try on recommendation from a friend and loved it - after a couple weeks expanded to the full game!   Quite the learning curve since I haven't done FPS since Black Ops II but overall, definitely worth playing!

One thing I would like to see with this game is ACTUAL rare items to add to the excitement.  I understand this game is driven by Tokens and COD points but why not add those as Ultra Rare Chest Drops.  100 COD Points or 1 token but a chance of dropping like 1 in a million+  I think it would really add to the excitement of the game and with a chance-drop rate that high, certainly wouldn't affect their "profit line", but would add some actual rare loot to the game that the players would be excited to find.

All in all, love it and hope they continue down this path!

personally, asside from the spawning issues, i enjoy the game. played the grand majority of popular shooters and I like the gunplay and OG maps of COD. I understand all of the issues people have with this game and how daunting all the issues are. Whenever I get on games i play to be competitive and hope others will do the same, MW2 and III being two of the only games that allows me to do that. I also understand the issues with the weapon leveling system and the store, but have not found any issues dealing with the "p2w" ideas, i pay for these things because my time on games are slowly dwindling with studies and an assortment of other things, and most of the people who pay for the broken items can be eliminated with weapons that were previously good and still decent, paired with playing smarter than other people and not rushing spawns with no regard as i see in my games. (I also payed for the vault edition for those wondering) 

Final verdict: I love the game! despite all of the issues with Activision and its developers, to me, the game is a fast paced, high octane, competitive, slighly buggy mess that wants to be the best it can. Play with caution, as you may be called slurs in vc ;)

Be smart, play safe and have a good day!

It feels like you're driving a tank with no tracks. The movement is slow, its clunky, everything about it feels either too bright or too blocky. The movement really is bad, prone feels like you're first person in mud runners, crawling through glue. The aiming is overly friendly which takes away skills.

The kills feel unsatisfying, there's very little bullet drop so it just feels too easy. You can really pick out enemies as it seems they made it to make everyone stick out like a sore thumb unless you buy the full black skins in the shop.

The vehicles are a mess, you can touch a box and a tank will fly up in the air, I never knew cardboard could be so strong! The smaller vehicles feel like you're in a pinball machine with the same control as you have when you're falling down the stairs. You take a lifetime to get to speed and you take another 2 life times to slow down or turn. Heaven forbid you want to do both, thats when things go very wrong.

Call of Duty is the best game ever made. It has everything you could ever want in a video game: realistic graphics, immersive sound effects, thrilling gameplay, and a deep story that will make you cry, laugh, and rage. You will never get bored of playing Call of Duty, because it offers endless variety and replay value. You can choose from dozens of modes, maps, weapons, and perks, and customize your character to suit your style. You can also team up with your friends online, or compete against other players from around the world. Call of Duty is not just a game, it is a lifestyle.

Call of Duty is also a masterpiece of art and design. The developers have put so much effort and passion into creating this game, that you can feel their love in every pixel. The game is flawless, bug-free, and optimized for every platform. The game also respects your time and money, and does not force you to buy any microtransactions or loot boxes. You get the full experience for a fair price, and you can enjoy it without any interruptions or advertisements. Call of Duty is the perfect example of how a game should be made.

Call of Duty is not just a game, it is a revolution. It has changed the gaming industry forever, and set a new standard for quality and innovation. No other game can compare to Call of Duty, and no other game will ever surpass it. Call of Duty is the ultimate game, and you owe it to yourself to play it. Trust me, you will not regret it. Call of Duty is the best thing that ever happened to humanity.

Got to level 55 and that was the last nail in the coffin for me and enjoying this game.  I was even willing to see past the tedious "win 2-5 matches or daily challenges to unlock" progression before that.  Then realized the level 55 weapons are trapped behind really stupid specific challenges like "get 50 hipfire smg kills" which is much dumber than armory unlocks.  I know you can technically unlock by finding them in zombies but I'm not wasting 40 minutes of my life playing that half baked crap for the chance to find what I want.  

Ranked play is in my opinion a better objective mode than regular multiplayer but the gun selection and customization is too limited for me.  I get the point is to not get op but the only novelty I find in this game is trying out different gun styles.  And you can't tell me the devs couldn't just balance the dps of different weapons to be more fair. 

Zombies as stated is a disappointment.  I would be able to tolerate it if there wasn't a time limit, as well as the stupid insured weapon crap (Honestly activision can it just be possible to try and enjoy your game?).  Multiplayer can be fun but half the time you're paired with campers and people who don't even do objectives.  Maybe I'm missing a game mode or something but I wish it was set up like ranked play and punished playing like a manic idiot while rewarding more decisive play.

Game plays really well, multiplayer is snappy and zombies is a ton of fun, but I can't recommend buying this game on steam. constant server issues including not being able to even log in, lag spikes, and the worst of all being signed out. It's not like an "every once in a while" thing either. I have dropped into a zombies game 6 times, I got disconnected from 3 of them. We've been making and playing CoD games for two decades now and they seem to steadily go downhill after every reboot. Good game, dog water experience.

I got mw3 after thoroughly disliking mw2, but having some of the best experiences on mw19. I had some friends strongly advising against it, but others who said they were loving it. Most of the bad reviews I saw prior to my purchase seem to indicate technical or server issues.

I'd recommend it for sure, but I also understand people not being happy with the cod model and recent products.

Fun game, brings back memories of some older Cods to an extent. However, the servers are so horrbile that I cannot play the game. Averaging speeds of 300mbps and above, the game still runs horrible. Im lucky if i can get a game with below 80ms latency in my own region. Fix the servers and the game would be great.

This reboot series are the first COD games I've played in a decade. I've thankfully have only experience one or two crashes in the 150 or so hours I've played this. The aim assist seems a little crazy, I play with a mouse and keyboard (as god intended pc players to play) but I've seen plenty of proof that controller aim assist is too much. The campaign deserves all the complaints it gets, the open world/dmz style levels are not good. No where as good as MW2019, not even close. You can avoid the microtransactions easily, as you can grind and get any weapon you want pretty easily and the dlc weapons don't give you anything actually useful, they are just skins and tuned, which you can tune without buying the dlc. People give this game too much shit, play hardcore and at least you know what to expect not horrible ttk on the mw2 weapons that transferred over and whatnot. Always hated the multiplayer in particular. I’m more of an open world Arma, Dayz type of player. 

BUT!!! And this is a big But. I’ve always loved the Campaigns. They are everything you need and want out of a single player story driven action packed campaign. 

Everyone is complaining about the mission structure in MW3. The open missions in particular. But I’ve actually  enjoyed them. As well as the campaign. 

They say it’s short. But it’s not. Not if you take your time and actually play it in a tactical way. MW2 I played on the hardest difficulty level. And it took me forever. This year I’m playing on normal and I’m having a blast. And it’s taking me a long time. Not 5 or so hours like people are saying. 

I bought MW3 for the campaign. And I’m going to enjoy it. Why rush something to get finished with it? Where’s the fun in that. 

It’s a gorgeous game. Some cutscenes I had to stop and just admire them. Everything looks so real. And it should! 

So if you’re on the fence, and you are not interested in the Multiplayer Kill box scenario but enjoy single player stories, give it a try.! 

I’ll probably play a little multiplayer after I finish the campaign and then I’ll end up leaving like always. Partly because I’m not very good and the other becuase I just never have liked the multiplayer aspect.

But the campaign is great. 

Dont listen to kids who cry about this and that. At its core, it’s a great, engaging, exciting campaign!

I have been playing Call of Duty since COD4 back on the 360/PS3. I have not missed a year.

Back then you could hop on and play after school or work and play a few games and relax. That just isn't the case anymore. Skill-based matchmaking has ruined casual play. Every single game is like fighting for my life to maintain a 1.0 KD. 

I used to always love showing off my KD. I never had an issue keeping my KD above a 2.0-2.5 in most COD games. Right now, after over 500 hours played, I have a 1.08 KD. Right where they want us to be. 

The only time I am able to get a fun game where I am able to get more than maybe a UAV in a match is after I don't play for a week. The game seems to know I need a warm up game first, so it purposefully throws me into a lobby with people that are noticeably lower gun skill than I am. It never fails that my first game back I will be able to drop 40+ kills and have single digit deaths. It makes you feel good. For a single match. 

The very next match is always a complete 180. I have to fight for my life just to get a kill. I will always end that game negative.

From then on for that gaming session, however long I can stand it(usually an hour or 2 before stopping for a week again) it will be just like it was. Fighting hard to stay above a 1 KD throughout the matches every single game.

Also probably an unpopular opinion, but I cannot stand that movement is so much faster nowadays. Everyone is just "Slide Cancelling" around corners and jump shooting to get head shots like they're playing Halo. And I'm not saying this because I'm unable to perform these mechanics. I will participate in said mechanics just so I can keep up with these people, but it's not enjoyable. I don't know why everyone is in such a hurry to get from one side of the map to the other. 

I never thought I'd leave a bad review on a game with over 500 hours on it, much less the games I've been playing for over 16 years. But after this last time of going through the same process of having one good game, one horrible game, and then 2 hours of fighting for 1 KD, I just cannot recommend the game anymore. It's not the game I grew up with. 

I have uninstalled Call of Duty for the last time. It's time I move on.

Thank you for all the years of enjoyment you've brought me.

While I understand the frustration of those who have played the entire franchise and find it repetitive, one cannot deny the meticulous attention to detail and overall quality of the game. As someone who doesn't typically play Call of Duty very often, I truly enjoy it. The inclusion of classic maps, impeccable sound design rivaling that of Tarkov, and lifelike gun animations are particularly impressive. I believe the criticism towards the game stems from spending excessive amounts of time, around 8-9 hours a day for years, which naturally leads to boredom as graphical improvements reach a plateau. While advancements in graphics are possible, they would likely require high-end hardware accessible to few. Personally, as someone who can only dedicate around 4 hours a day to gaming, I find the game highly enjoyable. The addition of fancy skins and visuals doesn't detract from the overall experience for me. There are numerous engaging game modes available, and even the zombies mode is surprisingly good. I think people are being overly critical of Modern Warfare III; perhaps they are simply playing it too much and becoming jaded. Right now, they need to take a step back and appreciate the game for what it offers.

So I know that I have a lot of hours on CoD, at face value, but most of those hours are from MWII.

This review is about MWIII. MWII has it's own issues, but most people aren't going to be buying that.

Do not buy. It's not worth the price tag. The game play isn't rewarding, it doesn't feel satisfying, and it will leave you burnt out and stressed. The game is over-commodified, in that that all Activision cares about is doing things that convince you to buy their microtransactions.

There are plenty of events where you can earn a multitude of rewards, but, to earn those rewards, you have to play frequently, and grind/farm like mad, often for very little visible reward, which is what will leave you burnt out. On top of that in every event, Activision offers special operator packs that will allow you to earn increased progress speed, to incentivize you to buy even more transactions.

It would be one thing if that was the only issue, but the matchmaking is also a problem, with the matchmaking favouring engagement over all else. The game will put you into just enough matches where your performance is good enough that you want to keep playing, and then dump you into a series of matches where you get beaten down again and again. 

There are psychological reasons for this that I won't pretend to understand, but the underlying principle is more or less; If you're angry from a loss, you're more likely to want to continue playing, to prove that you're better. And if you're still playing, then they still have the chance to sell you more microtransactions.

The entire game, from Activision's side, revolves around convincing you to buy these microtransactions.

This game is less of a fun way to pass the time, and more akin to a toxic and very destructive addiction.

Do NOT buy this game.

If you enjoy consistent, satisfying PVP gun-play with a fast paced, arcade feel, this base experience in early 2024 is absolutely worth 70$, pay to win factor is very light {alt. reticles, darker player models} and is not a major factor considering enemies have a colored dot above their head in the vast majority of modes.

- servers are consistently up, matchmaking is fast (~1 min from menu to match).
- consistent player counts and very good social tools (MUTE VOICE CHAT FIRST THING).
- the animations, models, and mechanics are high quality and dense.
- lots of different play-styles and weapons, if you like tinkering, you'll find over 100 unlockable weapons, the vast majority can be customized with attachments, camos, decals and cosmetics. camos and attatchments are free or unlockable.
- guns feel varied and have unique applications.
- juggling killstreaks makes you feel like a god.

It's mindless nonsense. The spawns are often terrible. There will be nobody around you, then the whole enemy team will spawn behind you or to your side. Obviously there is some type of 'skill' involved to separate the players that can't get a kill at all, compared to others who can go on long killstreaks, but in general it's a children's game of hide and seek or tag, because the time to kill is so low, there's little incentive to be good at aiming or maintaining your aim on a target. The low time to kill also promotes camping or hiding in corners. Snipers kill with 1hit body shots, so why would you ever aim for headshots? Sometimes all you may want to do is to run around like a maniac, kill die kill die kill die every 2 seconds, then Call Of Duty is for you. I used to like the older campaigns and Spec Ops missions were cool. I'm sure there are some newer Campaign modes that have some fun or interesting missions also, but as far as Multiplayer goes, it's pretty terrible except to just mess around with. That's what I'm doing.. I'm not taking it seriously at all, because it's not a quality multiplayer that involves any real skill. As far as stability in the way the game runs, it's been crashing my computer or the game itself crashes. I don't know the cause. Maybe I'm overheating, but the numbers I see don't show that so I don't know what the cause is. What's strange is I see CPU usage (temperature) gain significantly after a match finishes, when it's showing what you've unlocked and then as you're back in the lobby. Why? How is the CPU being stressed on a basic menu screen much more than actually being in-game.. it makes no sense to me.

Engaging Campaign: MW2 offers a gripping single-player campaign filled with intense action, memorable characters, and a storyline that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Whether you're storming a gulag, engaging in epic firefights, or participating in covert operations, the campaign delivers a cinematic experience that's hard to forget.

Iconic Multiplayer: MW2's multiplayer mode is legendary in the gaming community for its fast-paced gameplay, diverse maps, and addictive progression system. With customizable classes, killstreak rewards, and a wide range of weapons and equipment, the multiplayer offers endless replayability and competitive fun.

Memorable Moments: MW2 is filled with iconic moments that have become ingrained in gaming culture, such as the controversial "No Russian" mission, the adrenaline-pumping snowmobile chase, and the exhilarating finale that culminates in a showdown with a formidable foe.

Revolutionary Features: MW2 introduced several innovative features to the Call of Duty franchise, including customizable killstreaks, the introduction of the "Spec Ops" co-op mode, and the addition of the highly coveted Tactical Nuke killstreak reward, which instantly ends the match in victory for the team that calls it in.

Nostalgia and Legacy: For many gamers, MW2 holds a special place in their hearts as a nostalgic reminder of the golden age of Call of Duty. Whether you're revisiting it for the memories or experiencing it for the first time, MW2's enduring legacy ensures that it remains a must-play title for any fan of the franchise.

Overall, Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 is a timeless classic that offers a perfect blend of captivating storytelling, adrenaline-fueled gameplay, and unforgettable moments that continue to resonate with players years after its release. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, MW2 is an experience that shouldn't be missed.

Seeing as both MW2 and MW3 fall under this title on Steam, I'll put it into two sections.

Modern Warfare 2 (2022) 
- Not Recommended overall, the movement is clunky, the TTK is way too quick and although the campaign is decent for a Call of Duty, it feels like it lost the grip and realism of the MW19 campaign and ultimately it didn't raise the stakes very much, particularly if you compare it to the OG MW2. Warzone 2 I did not play at all so can not comment on it, DMZ seemed a good idea but I don't think the appeal for it is there compared to other games such as Escape From Tarkov.

Modern Warfare 3 (2023)
- Recommended, overall this game is pretty much an "DLC" to MW22, the graphics are precisely the same and you can use MW2 weapons on MW3 as well as attachments and so on. In terms of the multiplayer it is probably the second best in Post-2019 CoD with the exception of Cold War. The movement is fast paced, fluid and overall is similar to MW19 (though still not as good unfortunately) - new features such as Tac Stance are great for close quarters and are a gameplay addition that actually effect the average gameplay (unlike the destruction in Vanguard). The TTK allows for you to actually be able to react to getting shot and so you can reposition or if your better at aiming than your opponents, turn on them and outgun them. In terms of multiplayer, the maps are where this game fell short at launch because although the 2009 MW2 Maps are great, they aren't built for the current movement in CoD and so it does feel a bit clunky, alongside this it adds to the perception that this game was very rushed (which it was), however new original maps have been brought in through seasonal updates and these are good. The reintroduction of the War Mode is one of my favourite parts, there are only two maps as of me writing this however both are extremely fun to play on and accommodate a variety of play styles.

The main area where MW3 has fallen short is the campaign. Again, it is very clear this game was intended to be a DLC initially, and so the Campaign for MW3 is effectively in the Warzone map for the most part and plays just like Warzone. The stakes again are not risen and to be honest the campaign and story progression really has annoyed me as MW19 had laid such a good foundation that was never built on in its sequels.

In Short Campaign was quite good but felt like a filler excluding the ending as that was pretty good and also one or 2 other missions. 

Coop SUCKS so much that barely anyone plays it

Multiplayer is ok: less jump shotting idiots, Perks are a mess, Killstreaks are quite good, mixture of good and bad maps, guns are VERY hit and miss

Runs ok on pc no screen tear, might want to bump up the graphics as the maps can act weird without it. Updates are still BAD as you'll need to run the game to install further texture updates

4 months in: 

So this will focus more on multiplayer here. It's quite good but like I was saying before it has major issues which are UAVs.
As soon as an enemy UAV goes up you'll get rushed by every idiot on the planet. Can't even counter with ghost as there's a stupid timer for your perks to work. It does reduce camping but can limit what you can do especially if you have dumb teammates.

That bring me onto the next point. Weird asf team balancing?! Yes it can be that boring "sbm" or.... Lobbies where either you're destroying players that clearly suck or your stuck with them. There's no hope if your stuck with them as you can be amazing but if your teammates can't handle the other team your on your own all the time.

Summary play for the campaign and don't expect much from the multiplayer

Call of Duty: A Storage Nightmare

Rating: ★★☆☆☆

The most recent release in the Call of Duty franchise has left many players scratching their heads and frustrated with the direction the game has taken. While the graphics and gameplay remain top-notch, a significant flaw has emerged that is impossible to ignore – the excessive demand on storage space.

One of the most egregious issues is the mandatory download of all games within the series to play the latest installment. This decision has left players bewildered and annoyed, as the game requires an astronomical amount of storage space, making it impractical for those with limited resources on their gaming consoles or PCs.

The initial thrill of diving into the new Call of Duty quickly fades when faced with the reality of having to download and store games from previous years. This approach not only feels lazy on the part of the developers but also demonstrates a lack of consideration for players who may not have the luxury of unlimited storage.

The constant struggle to manage storage space has become a game in itself, forcing players to make difficult choices about which games to keep and which to delete to make room for the latest installment. This unnecessary burden detracts from the overall gaming experience and creates frustration rather than excitement.

the mandatory download of previous titles doesn't seem to serve any clear purpose in enhancing the gameplay of the new release. It appears to be a mere ploy to inflate the gamers storage have them to have less games on thier storage and have CoD the only game on storage they are able to play because the large storafe space it requires,

The decision to prioritize quantity over quality in terms of storage requirements is disappointing, especially for longtime fans who were eagerly anticipating a polished and streamlined gaming experience. With other titles offering innovative features and prioritizing user-friendly experiences, Call of duts latest move feels like a step in the wrong direction.

 while the graphics and core gamplay of the new call of duty installment may be commendable, the glaring issue of excessive storage demands significantly detracts from the overall enjoyment. It's a disappointing turn for a franchise that should be focused on delivering exceptional gaming experiences rather than burdening players with unnecessary storage concerns.

The game itself is decent (even though sometimes you get streaks of horrible spawnpoints and watch yourself die non stop for a while) but the servers and netcode are incredibly bad, especially if playing with friends from different regions or if you have even just average internet quality (rubberbanding, packet loss...) and that makes the game barely playable at times.

Matchmaking is also terribly inconsistent because it tries to force a 1:1 kd ratio, especially on small maps (where killstreaks and stun/flash really prevent healthy gameplay).

I can't recommend the game because of this, although some of the guns do feel quite good to shoot with.

Okay. so honest review

first of all lets talk about the pros of these games. (all of the recent recycled modern warfare games)

Pro: the game is OVERALL worth playing and having fun with. its a good way to meet friends or just kick back let off some steam.

Pro: it gives a variety of things to do and stuff to learn. new mechanics and game modes to understand slowly but surely. not only that BUT you low-key don't have to play any other game modes if you don't really want to. for example ill almost never play war-zone. its a lame excuse of a battle royal

Pro: as long as you dont have crappy internet it runs very smoothly. i didnt even have a graphics card for a while and it ran fine.

now its time for the Cons.

Con: the players are toxic. but that can be coinsidered a Pro sometimes to because im not friends with you unless your toxic.

Con: Strange performance. so MW2 runs fine but when it comes to MW3 it runs like a fat kid running form the cookie monster. fast but.... not right. 

Con: recycled: yes this game is literally a copy and a paste of the past 2 mw games but it is still fun. if you liked the first 2 youll like this one too

Conclusion: if your a Honest COD fan. and you can afford it. i recommend buying it on sale and playing for an hour and if you dont like it get a refund. hope this review helps. enjoy smashing your keyboard or controller like i smashed that guy who killed me's mom.

Despite having spent a lot of hours in the game I can't recommend it in its current state.

1) Several longstanding bugs just never get fixed, even though they are annoying as hell (e.g. "Your profile was signed out" or the constant insane package loss [despite having a very optimised internet connection]).
2) The campaign is just lazy and a bad attempt to re-tell a great story. 
3) The SBMM is out of control (I am not a great CoD player but neither am I a slouch - but after getting thrown into a match where I just get destroyed I get thrown into a match where the enemy feels like bots, only to then be thrown back into the first type of match... and this keeps happening constantly)
4) And then there are the micro-transactions, while they unfortunately have become a long standing component of CoD the skins [operator skins in particular] in this iteration are just plain bad. One microtransaction even charged you for the soundtrack of the original MW2 to be played in the main menu... - nothing but making you pay for memberberries

Now to be fair - the game has some good things about it (otherwise I wouldn't have sunk as many hours into it as I did)
1) The gunplay just feels good.
2) The Zombies and Warzone modes are just plain fun
3) A lot of memberberries for which you don't have to pay and allow you to revisit some beloved maps from previous installments in the series
4) The seasonal content provides reasons to return to the game

Overall: If you can get your hands on this game in a sale you could maybe consider buying it. If not - don't touch it, at least not for the core mode or the campaign.

[h1]This review are written for "campaign" to a brand new Call of Duty: Modern Warfare III, known as a 70$ DLC and "direct sequel" for a Call of Duty Modern Warfare II 2022. [/h1]

It will contain 3 segments: 

1. a story.
2. an atmosphere.
3. the technical stance.

Let's begin:

[h1]Story [/h1]

Modern Warfare franchise has always been about "the struggle of good against evil", where in the end "good" are always won. Joint missions, covert operations, high quality scenery, MilSim style etc.

This "campaign" has none of this. Story is clunky, short and non immersive. Caracters are weak. Even [b]Price [/b]! Story is weak. Ending is weak. And gives developers the opportunity to "milk money" from fans for this weak rebooted storyline for at least 1 time. Maybe 2 times [spoiler](possible MW4, MW5 games) [/spoiler].

Playing "campaign" feels similar to watch Fast and Furious. [spoiler]No one loves, but always watching. [/spoiler]

[h1]Atmosphere [/h1]

Non existing at all. As a fan, I was struggled to play this short "campaign" and forced to split is in 3 days. Open combat missions [spoiler](Warzone & DMZ tutorial)[/spoiler] is terrible and boring. No "meaningful dialogues" between me and my team. Only spam the same quotes that i "need to go somewhere to do something, else "they" will won and cause a big trouble".

Mission "No russian", that was hyped in the end of MW II, was a complete disaster and basically a "playable" cutscene.

MilSim style got worse. No good cammo and realistic patterns. Red accents -- for bad guys, blue -- for good. No uniqueness in enemies.

The overall direction of missions is weak and forced. Feels like i am playing this weird CO-OP without random players.

[h1]Technical stance [/h1]

Descent. I've got a bug or two this and there. Not critical. From another standpoint, this game is a pure cannibalism of previous games in this franchise. Same mechanics, models, textures and VFX'es. 
But worse! I don't know how they manage to do this..

[h1]Conclusion [/h1]

Overall, this is the worst campaign in this franchise ([spoiler]including an OG MW games [/spoiler]). The funny and sad is that, that I've said the same thing for MW II...

But somehow, Infinity Ward, Sledgehammer Games, Treyarch, Beenox and Activision Blizzard overcome themselves and publish a worse product that they did last year.

I am shure, that all of these people, who works in these studios, need's to be fired and the studios are need's to be closed. Once and forever. They all have no respect in the community of devs and players. More of that, Fanbase are haiting them all, arguing, and saying out loud that "they did all it wrong". 

That's the story.. and this review. 

As a fan of MW series, i will never buy a single product from this devs (Infinity Ward, Sledgehammer Games, Treyarch, Beenox, etc.), that got maked in a short period of time (1 year or less). This is HILARIOUS, that so much people making this game and it is still BAD.

No microtransactions will be bought, no battle passes (and battle passes for battle passes) will be bought too. Never!

[spoiler]F*ck you all [/spoiler]!

This is the last 70$ from me to you, cash grabbers. Enjoy it. 

I've had enough.

P.S: Ah, btw.. The prisoner, numbered ‘627’ -- is a Capitain Price! Learn the lore, FFS. Watch: https://youtu.be/A9FCCvXLmW8?t=737

🔫 Gameplay Experience
⭐ Grounded mechanics
🔹 Slower and less fluid
🔹 Terribly inconsistent hit detection
🔹 Confusing wallbang mechanics

🎨 Graphics & Maps
⭐ High-quality graphics
🔹 Unusual color choices and aesthetics
🔹 Well-made classic maps with sporadic drawbacks
 
🎮 Multiplayer & Combat
⭐ Similar classic CoD experience
🔹 Disruptive spawns
🔹 Unfair controller aim assist

🎭 Campaign & Updates
⭐ Above average campaign
🔹 Narratively lacking, forced edginess
🔹 Odd update decisions and out-of-place skins

Gameplay Experience: A Study in Inconsistencies

🔫 Mechanics & Gunplay:
The game embarks on a more grounded, tactical route, favoring a realistic military shooter experience. While this decision could be commendable, the gameplay suffers from inconsistencies, resulting in a slower, less fluid gaming experience. A particular issue lies in erratic hit detection and the inexplicable inconsistency in delivering damage. The wallbang mechanics, a notable feature in previous versions, show glaring inconsistencies, leading to a lack of realistic strategy in gameplay dynamics.

🔫 Gunplay & Animation Details:
Despite these challenges, the sound design and animation details are commendable. The guns boast intricate and captivating animations, featuring meticulous details such as full and empty inspections, diverse reload animations, and high-fidelity models. However, these animation details and high-quality sounds fail to translate into a consistent or satisfying gameplay experience.

Graphics & Maps: Striking Visuals and Uneven Design Choices

🎨 Visuals & Aesthetics:
From a pure graphical standpoint, the game delivers stunning visuals that could easily be considered superior. Yet, the overall aesthetic choices, including color selection, LUTs, and design decisions, might seem inconsistent and at times, subpar. The reliance on photogrammetry scans for 3D models, while trying to imbue realism, inadvertently uses low-quality and unrealistic real-life equipment. The result is a jarring dichotomy that affects the game's overall visual coherence.

🗺️ Maps & Design:
Despite the visual appeal, the map design is predominantly impressive, showcasing a mix of classic and new maps. However, experimental maps like Santa Sena Border Crossing detract from the overall map design. The issue lies in the erratic spawning system, leading to players spawning in the middle of active gunfights or excessively close to enemy positions, hampering the overall gaming experience.

Multiplayer & Combat: Nostalgia Meets Unfair Competition

🎮 Multiplayer Dynamics:
The multiplayer experience remains true to the Call of Duty formula but introduces a different scenario for PC players with the inability to disable crossplay. The drawbacks include console players hotmicing music, as well as an overly strong aim assist that creates an uneven playing field, favoring controller users.

🔫 Weapon Mechanics:
Weapons feature a detailed and captivating design with appealing animations. However, the inclusion of seemingly redundant separate weapons takes away from potential customization options. Despite the intriguing design, weapon inconsistencies and gameplay mechanics remain a sticking point.

Campaign & Updates: A Narrative Miss and Skewed Customizations

🎭 Campaign Narrative:
The game's campaign, while attempting to deliver an above-average gaming experience, fails to present a compelling and coherent narrative. Betrayals within the storyline feel predictable and lack the emotional depth seen in previous iterations.

🔧 Updates & Customization:
The game's updates frequently yield controversial outcomes, impacting the game's overall balance. The inclusion of skins such as Nikki Minaj and 21 Savage appears incongruent with the realistic theme and draws criticism for deviating from the core military and modern warfare essence.

Summing up, the game weaves together impressive strengths and critical drawbacks, displaying a mix of progress and areas that urgently need refinement and enhancements across various facets of gameplay and overall experience.

A horrible operating and menu system including load outs. If your on computer, you are in on a surprise. This game was built for a controller. If you have 4k monitor or curved, be ready to make adjustments that never seem to work right. The sensitivity and bullet registration is horrible. If you don't have an fov of at least 100, your sniper bullets won't hit long shots. Numerous bugs and glitches. I almost feel like the owe me the other half of the game. Graphics are a pain to adjust because it doesn't seem to self adjust with their onboard operating system. I had to change the thread count in documents to get it somewhat properly working so my computer won't bottleneck. I think Activision should pay me to play this worst horrendous COD I have ever played as far as the OS goes or their UI. The game itself and multiplayer experience is a great idea but, the mechanics in making the game work on PC is terrible. I don't even know why this game is even up for game of the year?
